snippet: Nearly three months after Hurricane Sandy, the Jersey Shore feels more like a demilitarized zone than a seaside haven.
abstract: Towns along the New Jersey shore, nearly three months after Hurricane Sandy, feel more like demilitarized zones than seaside havens; some towns are still under an evacuation order from the governor and are not allowing people into their homes or imposing checkpoints and curfews; residents say they feel overwhelmed by continual sight of devastation and unanswered questions about when they will be allowed to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after Hurricane Sandy, the Jersey Shore feels more like a demilitarized zone than a seaside haven.

headline.seo: Checkpoints and Curfews Replace Carefree at Jersey Shore
headline.main: Police Barricades and Curfews Wear on Jersey Shore Nerves
headline.print_headline: Police Barricades and Curfews Wear on Jersey Shore Nerves
